title-group.article-title: Sensation-Seeking Profiles and Personal Innovativeness in Information Technology

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Jesús Manuel López-Bonilla is an associate professor, Department of Business Administration and Marketing. He received his PhD in marketing from the University of Seville, Spain. His current major research areas are consumer behavior, technologies and innovations, and tourism research. He has presented his findings at conferences in Europe and published several articles on these areas in international journals.

Luis Miguel López-Bonilla is an associate professor at the Department of Business Administration and Marketing. He received his PhD in marketing from the University of Seville, Spain. His major areas of empirical fieldwork include adoption innovations, self-service technologies, consumer behavior, and tourism marketing. He has presented his findings at conferences in Europe and published several articles on these areas in international journals.

abstract.p: Sensation seeking has been studied extensively. However, the study of sensation-seeking profiles is still very limited in the literature and even more so in the area of information and communication technology (ICT). The present study analyzes sensation seeking and the innovative behavior of individuals in the use of information technologies. This work explores the connection between two individual personality traits: sensation seeking (from a social psychology perspective) and personal innovativeness in ICT (from marketing and information systems perspectives). An empirical study was carried out on a sample of 819 university students. The authors have analyzed 12 profiles, which were obtained from the combination of the four traits of the Sensation-Seeking scale. The results confirmed the relationship between both constructs in three sensation-seeking profiles.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Information and communication technologies (ICTs) have assumed a critically important role in almost every facet of our society (Roussos, 2007). Due to the growth of the ICTs in recent years, it is important for academic researchers to understand individual usage and perceptions of these technologies. In general, the individual personality differences of those who adopt ICTs are still very little explored. Sensation seeking (SS) could be considered as a trait relevant to the adoption of the ICTs.

SS has been studied extensively. However, the study of sensation-seeking profiles is still very limited in the literature and even more so in the area of ICT. This is why the present study analyze SS and the innovative behavior of individuals in the use of information technologies. Theoretically, sensation seekers should be good candidates for the adoption of new information technologies because they seek out novel experiences. SS is made up of four dimensions: thrill and adventure seeking (TAS), experience seeking (ES), disinhibition (Dis), and boredom susceptibility (BS). In the present study, sensation-seeking profiles are obtained from a combination of the four traits of the Sensation-Seeking scale.

This study explores the connection between two individual personality traits: SS (from a social psychology perspective) and personal innovativeness in information technologies (PIIT; from marketing and information systems perspectives). According to the latest definition of SS by Zuckerman (1994, p. 27), this is “a trait defined by the seeking of varied, novel and complex experiences, and the willingness to take physical, social, legal and financial risks for the sake of such experience.” The term SS was coined to describe the trait that includes a variety of risk-taking and sensation-seeking behaviors and the expressed intolerance for boredom (Pizam, Jeong, Reichel, & Van Boemmel, 2004). Galloway and Lopez (1999) indicate that SS has been found to be positively correlated with risk-taking behavior, a tendency to disclose personal thoughts and feelings, dislikes of structured and formal situations, adventure travel, a tendency to avoid repetition, a linking of intense experiences, a proneness to boredom under restrained and repetitive situations, and a tendency toward Dis.

On the other hand, personal innovativeness (PI) helps identify individuals who are likely to adopt information technology innovations earlier than others (Agarwal & Prasad, 1998). As Rogers (1995) suggests, such individuals can then serve as key change agents and opinion leaders to facilitate further diffusion of a new technology. PIIT is a construct created by Agarwal and Prasad (1998). These authors define PIIT as the willingness of an individual to try out any new information technology.

Despite the importance of information technology in recent years, few studies have been carried out on the relationship between SS and the use of information technology (Etter, Cramer, & Finn, 2006; López-Bonilla & López-Bonilla, 2008; Martin, Sherrard, & Wentzel, 2005). Besides, we found no studies that analyze the profiles that determine sensation seekers according to their four traits. The purpose of this investigation is to understand this issue better and cover this gap in the literature.

sec.title: Theoretical Framework
sec.p: As mentioned above, this article studies the connection between two individual personality traits: SS and PIIT. Hurt, Joseph, and Cook (1977) noted that innovativeness is viewed as a personality trait reflecting a willingness to change. This is a psychological trait postulated to underlie adoption behavior (Leavitt & Walton, 1975). Chau and Hui (1998) indicated that consumer innovativeness is a concept studied in consumer psychology as a link to the adoption of new products. Following Chau and Hui (1998), two distinct conceptualizations of the nature of consumer innovativeness have been proposed and developed by Midgley and Dowling (1978) and Hirschman (1980). Midgley and Dowling (1978) classified innovativeness into different abstract levels: the highest level being “innate innovativeness.” This was seen as a generalized personality trait possessed more or less by every member of society and defined as “the degree to which an individual makes innovation decisions independently of the communicated experience of others.” However, Hirschman (1980) indicated that innovativeness is more likely to be socially influenced than a personality trait. She proposed the idea of “inherent novelty seeking,” which is the desire of the individual to seek out novel stimuli. As Manning, Bearden, and Madden (1995) pointed out, Hirschman’s conceptualization of innovativeness centers on consumer desires to obtain information about innovations. Hence, Hirschman defined innovativeness as a more abstract or higher order trait than did Midgley and Dowling (Carlson & Grossbart, 1984; Manning, Bearden, & Madden, 1995; Subramanian & Mittelstaedt, 1992).

PI is a construct that has had a long-standing tradition in innovation diffusion research in general (e.g., Agarwal & Prassad, 1998; Agarwal, Sambamurthy, & Stair, 2000; Chau & Hui, 1998; Lu, Yao, & Yu, 2005; Rogers, 1983, 1995; Yi, Fiedler, & Park, 2006) and the domain of marketing in particular (e.g., Cotte & Wood, 2004; Flynn & Goldsmith, 1993; Goldsmith & Hofacker, 1991; Goldsmith & Newel, 1997; Herrero & Rodríguez, 2008; Leavitt & Walton, 1975; Manning et al., 1995; Midgley & Dowling, 1978; Roehrich, 2004; Park, Yu, & Zhou, 2010). Flynn and Goldsmith (1993) noted a distinction between global innovativeness and domain-specific innovativeness. Thus, global innovativeness exhibits a low predictive power when applied to any specific innovation adoption decision (Leonard-Barton & Deschamps, 1988; Goldsmith & Hofacker, 1991). However, domain-specific innovativeness is posited to exhibit significant influence on behaviors within a narrow domain of activity (Goldsmith & Hofacker, 1991).

In this sense, Agarwal and Prasad (1998) have created a construct of innovativeness in the domain of information technology (PIIT). This is defined as a relatively stable descriptor of individuals that is invariant across situational considerations. This trait captures the risk-taking propensity of an individual with regard to information technology (Agarwal et al., 2000). This definition is derived from the articles of Midgley and Dowling (1987) and Flynn and Goldsmith (1993).

On the other hand, the personality of individuals with high scores in SS corresponds to a high degree of autonomy, expresses their emotions openly, is nonconformist, takes risks, acts regardless of social conventions and of the needs and attitudes of others and organizes their lives in order to maximize the opportunities of self-fulfilment. Zuckerman (1991) considers it probable that those who actively participate in sensation-seeking work well under conditions which include an excess of stimulation, although antisocial behavior can also be produced in less demanding situations. People who take little part in SS adapt better to the majority of everyday situations, whereas they can be thrown off balance when these situations become more intense.

The Sensation-Seeking scale is made up of four dimensions (Zuckerman, 1983): (a) ES, which represents the seeking of experience through the mind and senses, manifested as travel and a nonconforming lifestyle; (b) BS, representing an aversion to repetition and routine, and restlessness when things are not changing; (c) TAS, expressed as a desire to engage in sports or other activities involving speed or danger; and (d) Dis, which represents the desire to be socially and sexually uninhibited.

Since the construction of the first Sensation-Seeking scale in the early 1960s, the concept of SS has been extensively researched (Brakto & Butkovic, 2003). An abundance of literature exists on SS and socially deviant behaviors. SS is not only related to antisocial or norm-breaking behavior. Michel et al. (1999) pointed out that SS is a normal personality trait, but is also linked to psychopathic phenomena. However, studies on SS and normal behavior are becoming more frequent. For example, SS is related to sports (Bouter, Knipschild, Feij, & Volovics, 1988; Breivik, 1996; Gomà-I-Freixanet, 1991; Michael, Carton, & Jouvent, 1997; Zuckerman, 1979), leisure (Barnett, 2006; Galloway, 2002; Hong & Jang, 2004; Schrader & Wann, 1999; Zuckerman, 1979, 1993, 1994), consumer behavior (Hanna & Wangle, 1989; Steenkamp & Baumgartner, 1992), communications (Rowland, Fouts, & Hetherton, 1989), financial risk (Wong & Carducci, 1991), innovative behavior (Burns & Krampf, 1992; Foxall, 1993), fashion (Workman & Johnson, 1993), advertising (Leone & D’Arienzo, 2000; Schoenbachler & Whittler, 1996), travel behavior (Gilchrist, Povey, Dickinson, & Povey, 1995; Lepp & Gibbson, 2008; Pizam et al., 2004), promotional games (McDaniel, 2002), employment (Roth, 2003), investment risk (Corter & Chen, 2005), website design (Martin et al., 2005), ethical behavior (Etter et al., 2006), cooperative behavior (Kimmerle, Cress, & Hesse, 2007), and Internet use (Armstrong, Phillips, & Saling, 2000; López-Bonilla & López-Bonilla, 2008; Martin et al., 2005; Weiser, 2000; Weisskirch & Murphy, 2004).

An objective of this study is to examine the relationship between SS and PIIT. In this sense, as Self and Findley (2006) described, SS and innovativeness are related. To the authors' knowledge only this study has investigated this issue. Wymer, Self, and Findley (2010) pointed out that each concept relates to an individual’s desire for experience and stimulation and, furthermore, both factors would motivate individuals to desire new experiences. Hanna and Wagle (1989) suggested that high sensation seekers are more likely than low sensation seekers to be consumer innovators who tend to purchase new products. Mittelstaedt, Grossbart, Curtis, and Devere (1976) affirm that high sensation seekers would be more aware of new alternatives, consider more alternatives and, reject less on the basis of cognitive evaluation alone, would try and ultimately adopt more innovations. However, Steenkamp and Baumgartner (1992), for example, found no relationship between the role of the optimum stimulation level in innovative behavior toward a specific product.

Few studies have made the connection between SS and IT use (López-Bonilla & López-Bonilla, 2010). Regarding the four dimensions of SS, previous studies have found that Dis and BS were related to Internet abuse (Chaney & Chang, 2005; Lin & Tsai, 2001; Velezmoro, Lacefield, & Roberti, 2010). Also, in the comparison between e-shoppers and non-e-shoppers, significant differences have been appreciated in the subscale of TAS (López-Bonilla & López-Bonilla, 2008). Therefore, the following research hypothesis is considered: SS positively influences the PIIT. But we will test this hypothesis in several sensation-seeking profiles.

Furthermore, one wonders who are considered as sensation seekers. In principle, sensation seekers are those with high scores in the Sensation-Seeking scale. But SS consists of four subscales or dimensions: TAS, ES, Dis, and BS. It is necessary to know whether sensation seekers are made up of individuals with high scores in all four traits or there are sensation seekers with high scores in some traits and neutral or low scores in other traits. To do so, it is necessary to perform a previous study on the sensation-seeking profiles. Different groups of individuals must be extracted according to the combination of the four traits of the Sensation-Seeking scale. Once these groups are obtained the relationship between SS and PIIT will be checked for each group. Thereby, the main goal of this article is focused on a deeper understanding of who are sensation seekers and what their basic features regarding ICT adoption are. Despite the wide number of studies carried out on SS and its increasing interest as a normal personality trait, we found no studies that analyze the profiles that determine sensation seekers according to their four traits. That is, the traits of SS have been studied independently but not in a combined way.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: A sample of 819 undergraduate business administration students (F = 515, M = 304; average age of 21.4) from a big south European university (University of Seville, Spain) was obtained for this study. Research has suggested that college students tend to use a variety of Internet functions (Morahan-Martin & Schumacher, 2000). This sample seemed appropriate for the exploratory nature of this study.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: A convenience sampling technique was employed for data collection in this study. Self-administered questionnaires were used. Several groups of students completed the questionnaires in a classroom setting. Participation was voluntary and confidential. The authors were physically present in these classrooms, informing and controlling the tests at all times.

sec.title: Instrument
sec.p: The present study uses two scales: PIIT and the Brief Sensation-Seeking scale (BSSS; see Appendix A). All items were measured on a 7-point Likert-type scale ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (7), with the midpoint labelled neutral.

One scale is the PIIT, developed by Agarwal and Prassad (1998), that is measured by 4 items. Agarwal and Prassad (1998) argue that PI is an important concept for examining the acceptance of information technology innovations. These authors define PIIT, as “the willingness of an individual to try out any new information technology.” Roehrich (2004) indicated that this type of scale has been expressly designed to measure innovativeness as a tendency to buy new products. This scale was found reliable and valid by other studies (e.g., Agarwal et al., 2000; Agarwal & Karahanna, 2000; Herrero & Rodríguez, 2008; Serenko, 2008; Thatcher & Perrewe, 2002).

Another scale is the BSSS. This scale was created by Hoyle, Stephenson, Palmgreen, Lorch, and Donohew (2002) by adapting items from the Sensation Seeking Scale-Form V (SSS-V) (Zuckerman, Eysenck, & Eysenck, 1978). The BSSS is a viable measure of SS for adolescents and young adults and each of the four primary dimensions of SS is represented by 2 items (Hoyle et al., 2002). The psychometric properties of the BSSS has been confirmed by other studies (e.g., Eachus, 2004; Litvin, 2008; López-Bonilla & López-Bonilla, 2010).

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: We carried out the psychometric assessment of the two variables (SS and PIIT) through latent structure analysis and internal consistency analysis. Confirmatory factor analysis was done with the estimation method known as partial least squares (PLS). This was used by means of the software application PLS Graphs 3.0, designed by Chin (1998).

PLS is a limited estimation method denominated in this way by dividing the list of parameters to be estimated into various subsets by means of using multiple linear regressions which employ the algorithm of the ordinary least squares. The principal aim of PLS is to explain the variances of the endogenous variables, which is why it tends to be a good tool for finding the cause which significantly determines the behavior of these variables. PLS is an approach to structural equation modeling. In contrast to applications such as Linear Structural Relations (LISREL) (Structural Equation Modeling [SEM] technique based on covariance), PLS is based on variance. As Chin (1998) points out, this technique is particularly appropriate in the case of small samples with non-normal data.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 gathers the descriptive data of the SS and PIIT, with the totals and divided by gender. The mean value and, in brackets, the value of its standard deviation is indicated in each case. First, the Sensation-Seeking scale clearly reaches a score slightly higher than PIIT (5.10 vs. 4.41). “Experience seeking,” which shows very high scores for both men and women, stands out among the traits of the SS. However, women show higher scores in the traits of ES and BS, while men show higher scores in TAS and Dis. Likewise, the subscale of Dis shows the greatest differences in scores between both genders (women 4.09 vs. men 4.85). As for the PIIT scale, men show higher scores than women (4.72 vs. 4.23).

fn.p: Means are reported, with standard deviation in parentheses.

sec.p: First, a confirmatory analyses of the SS and PIIT scales on the whole sample was carried out. The reliability in both cases was checked (although the Sensation-Seeking scale keeps the last 4 items, removing the first 4). The reliability analysis of the BSSS is the following: Average Variance Extracted (AVE) = 0.5677; α Cronbach = 0.7442. And the reliability analysis of the PIIT is AVE = 0.6909; α Cronbach = 0.852. Likewise, the fact that the BSSS exerts a significant influence on the PIIT is corroborated (β = .2131; p < .001; R 2 = .0454). This test was also performed in the groups of men and women separately. Thereby, it was proved that the SS influences the PIIT significantly both in the case of men (β = .2113; p < 0.001; R 2 = .0332) and women (β = .2474; p < .001; R 2 = .0612). However, it can be seen that the values of the R 2 are not greater than .1, as Falk and Miller (1992) suggest.

Second, an analysis of the sensation-seeking profiles was performed, which is the main purpose of this study. There are multiple combinations of sensation-seeking profiles. In our study, 45 profiles were detected, although many of them are poorly represented. The sensation-seeking profiles, which exceed at least five individuals, are included in Table 2 . The letters represent each profile, which correspond to the following terms: A = High, B = Low, and N = Neutral. “High” is an average value between the 2 items of each subscale of SS that is above 4. “Low” is an average value of each subscale of SS that is below 4. N is the neutral value, which means an average value of 4. The first letter of each profile corresponds to the ES, the second letter stands for BS, the third letter is for TAS, and the fourth letter corresponds to D. Note that this table only includes those profiles with, at least, five sample elements.

Table 2 includes a sensation-seeking profile that stands out from the rest regarding the number of its sample elements and is 37.6% of the total sample. This profile is represented by high values in all four traits of SS. The second largest profile (9% of the total sample) is represented by high values in ES and BS and low values in TAS and D. The third largest profile (7.3% of the total sample) is represented by high values in ES, BA, and TAS and low values in D. And the fourth largest profile (7.1%) is made up of high values in ES and low values in the other traits. From the fifth profile, sample sizes are small, below 5% of the total sample.

As a basic assumption, a direct relationship is established between SS and innovativeness in the ICTs (PIIT) for the total sample and for each one of the profiles. These profiles are those with, at least, 20 individuals. Therefore, 12 sensation-seeking profiles were selected. First, to examine these relationships, Spearman and Kendall τ correlation coefficients were used to estimate and test the correlations between the BSSS and PIIT average scores. Table 3 shows the individual correlations between the two scales. Only one significant positive correlation is observed: profile 9.

Then, the structural analysis through PLS was performed. Hence, the relationships between SS and PIIT are shown in Table 4 . We indicate the paths and p values in each of the 12 profiles. It turned out that only three sensation-seeking profiles proved to be significant. These are the HNHH profile (R 2 = .219), with high values in three traits (ES, TAS, and D) and neutral values in BS; the HHLH profile (R 2 = .1714), with high values in three traits (ES, BS, and D) and low values in TAS; and the HLHL profile (R 2 = .2617), with high values in two traits (ES and TAS) and low values in the other two traits (BS and D). We have included the variances (R 2) of the dependent variables explained by the independent variables in each of the three profiles. It can be noted that PIITs were very well expounded, and exceed the minimum recommended by Falk and Miller (1992).

caption.p: Causal Relationships Between SS and PIIT

sec.p: Next, a second analysis was performed based on gender differences, focusing on the three significant profiles above. In the case of men, the three profiles exert a significant influence on innovativeness: R 2 (HHLH) = .7767; R 2 (HLHL) = .7346; R 2 (HNHH) = .6867. However, in the case of women, HLHL is the only profile with a significant influence (R 2 = .3819).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As the most obvious conclusion, we believe we have opened a new study line within SS. This is the study of profiles that identify sensation seekers. To our knowledge, there is no other research on this issue. Hence, the article is a first step in exploring the sensation-seeking profiles.

First, we observed in our descriptive analysis that there are multiple combinations of sensation-seeking profiles, although 61% of the sample is concentrated in four profiles: HHHH (37.6%), HHLL (9.04%), HHHL (7.33%), and HLLL (7.08%). It was shown that there is a sensation-seeking profile standing out from the rest regarding the number of its sample elements. This is 37.6% of the total sample. This profile is represented by high values in the four traits of SS. Thereby, we can assure that this profile mostly represents young adults. Thus, the second profile with more individuals is characterized by having high values in the traits ES and BS, and low values in the other two traits (TAS and Dis). This profile is only 9% of the total sample of individuals. Likewise, practically the entire sample showed itself to be identified with high values in the trait ES (specifically, 98.5%).

On the other hand, our causal analysis confirmed the relationship between SS and innovativeness in ICTs, both in the total sample and in the samples of men and women separately. These results are consistent with the study of Self and Findley (2006). However, in our study we discussed the sensation-seeking profiles in order to find out which of them confirm the hypothesis proposed.

To do this, we focused on the 12 profiles with a greater sample size—86.7% of individuals in the whole sample. The results of the study indicate that there are only three sensation-seeking profiles that significantly influence ICT innovativeness. Specifically, these profiles are: HHLH (high values in ES, BS, and D and low values in TAS), HLHL (high values in ES and D and low values in BS and TAS) and HNHH (high values in ES, TAS, and D and neutral values in BS).The most significantly influential profile is HNHH, followed by HHLH and HLHL. ES is the only trait that shows high values in these three significant profiles, therefore we assume it could be the most influential factor in the innovative behavior in the area of ICTs. Thereby, we could say that innovative behavior is related to the high values in the trait ES and a combination of the other traits with high, low or neutral values.

Furthermore, contrary to what one might think, the profile HHHH is not significant. Nevertheless, the profile HNHH is very close, only the trait BS being neutralized. This profile HNHH reaches the highest average score in the total scale of BS (5.43). But the other two significant profiles have an average score of 5.06 for HHLH and 4.26 for HLHL in the total scale. This last case has the lowest score among the 12 profiles studied.

These results allow us to question such a direct relationship established between sensation seekers and innovators. First, we should consider who the sensation seekers are, that is, which traits make up their profile. Obtaining high values in all traits is not enough to identify a sensation seeker. Thereby, the sensation seekers may also be individuals with low or neutral scores in a trait or some traits of SS, such as BS, TAS, or Dis. What we can confirm in this study is that the sensation seeker, considered as an innovator in the area of ICTs, seems to be identified with a high score in ES. Therefore, we believe the use of SS, in any study, should regard the profiles that make up the samples used. Identifying these profiles is fundamental to contrast the relationships between SS and other study variables.

As for gender, the three innovative profiles turned out to be related to men. On the other hand, there is only one innovative profile that stands out in women. In fact, this profile shows the most balanced scores between high and low values in the four traits, the high values being in ES and TAS and the low values in BS and D. This could indicate that the innovative profile of women is determined by other factors different from those of SS.

It is necessary to perform further studies that include an even wider sample, in order to test the influence of more secondary profiles, such as those in which ES is low in individuals. But a greater sample size is also necessary to study the influence of men and women in a greater number of profiles.

This study has some limitations that relate to the measurement and interpretation of the results. The use of self-reported scales to measure both independent and dependent variables may imply the possibility of a common method bias for the results. Such a bias could be minimized with a replication of the study using a longitudinal study approach. Moreover, the result of these sensation-seeking profiles must be checked with other samples, either different and more heterogeneous populations or different student populations in different places of the world. Our convenience sample is geographically restricted and limits the generalizability of the results. However, as Calders, Phillips, and Tybout (1981) argued, it is not so unsuitable for the data used to be inappropriate for testing a theory.

Finally, future investigations may be considered in the field of psychology and consumer behavior. Thus, from a psychological perspective, the relationship between the sensation-seeking profiles and the three basic personality traits of Eysenck (extraversion, neuroticism, and psychoticism) may be analyzed. Hence, for instance, some authors state that SS is part of extraversion (Eysenck, 1983; Eysenck & Eysenck, 1985) and some other authors prefer to consider it as part of psychoticism (Chico & Vázquez, 1999; Haapasalo, 1990; Zuckerman, Kuhlman, & Camat, 1988), and actually there are also some other authors who place SS between both personality traits (Eysenck & Eysenck, 1978; González, Ibánez, Peñate, Fumero, & García, 2001). We believe that determining the sensation-seeking profiles could bring more clarity to these differences. Likewise, from a consumer behavior perspective, the influence of sensation-seeking profiles regarding multiple Internet uses may be studied, such as e-mails, chats, forums, or social networks, as well as the attitudes and purchase intentions of users.

I would like to take off on a trip with no preplanned routes or timetables.
I get restless when I spend too much time at home.
I prefer friends who are excitingly un predictable.
I like to do frightening things.
I would like to try bungee jumping.
I would love to have new and exciting experiences, even if they are illegal.

sec.title: PI in the Domain of Information Technology scale:

list-item.p: If I heard about a new information technology, I would look for ways to experiment with it.
Among my peers, I am usually the first to try out new information technologies.
In general, I am hesitant to try out new information technologies.
I like to experiment with new information technologies.
